Using spherical polar coordinates \((r, \theta, \phi)\), evaluate the integral \(\iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S}\) where \(\underline{F} = r \cos \theta\underline{\hat{r}}\) and \(S\) is the curved surface of the top half of the sphere \(r = a\).

generalfeedback.text:
Using spherical polar coordinates \((r, \theta, \phi)\), we aim to evaluate the integral \(\iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S}\) where \(\underline{F} = r \cos \theta\underline{\hat{r}}\) and \(S\) is the curved surface of the top half of the sphere \(r = a\).

First to calculate \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S}\), we know that \(r = a\), and so can parametrise in terms of just \(\mathrm{d}\theta\) and \(\mathrm{d}\phi\). We know that the unit normal for a sphere around the centre in polar coordinates is \(\underline{\hat{n}} = \underline{\hat{r}}\), so that gives us that \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} =\underline{\hat{r}}\mathrm{d}\theta \mathrm{d}\phi\). Considering the bounds of the outer integral we observe that the upper bound can be \(\phi = 2\pi\) and the lower bound is \(\phi = 0\). For the inner integral the upper bound can be \(\theta = \frac{\pi}{2}\) and the lower bound is \(\theta = 0\). Bearing in mind that the Jacobian for spherical polar coordinates is \(J = r^2\sin\theta\) this gives us the following integral: \[ \begin{aligned} \iint_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} &= \int^{\phi = 2\pi}_{\phi = 0} \int^{\theta = \frac{\pi}{2}}_{\theta = 0} a \cos \theta\underline{\hat{r}} \cdot \underline{\hat{r}}\ \mathrm{d}\theta\ \mathrm{d}\phi a^2\sin\theta\\ &=\int^{\phi = 2\pi}_{\phi = 0} \int^{\theta = \frac{\pi}{2}}_{\theta = 0} \frac{1}{2}\sin(2\theta) a^3\ \mathrm{d}\theta\ \mathrm{d}\phi\\ &= \int^{\phi = 2\pi}_{\phi = 0} \left[ -\frac{1}{4}\cos (2\theta) a^3 \right]^{\theta = \frac{\pi}{2}}_{\theta = 0}\ \mathrm{d}\phi\\ &= \int^{\phi = 2\pi}_{\phi = 0} \frac{a^3}{2}\ \mathrm{d}\phi\\ &= \left[ \frac{a^3}{2}\phi \right]^{\phi = 2\pi}_{\phi = 0}\\ &= \pi a^3 \end{aligned} \]
